explanation:
Explain why each symbol is required for analyzing unreachable code in answer_to_connection:

- struct connection_info_struct: The function allocates and dereferences this type; its layout (fields used) determines which code paths depend on its members.
- connection_info_struct::answerstring: The code tests con_info->answerstring to decide a return path (send_page). Whether this field can be non-NULL affects reachability of that branch.
- connection_info_struct::postprocessor: Stored from MHD_create_post_processor and later passed to MHD_post_process; its presence or absence controls branching and potential early returns.
- connection_info_struct::connectiontype: Set to POST or GET; although not used further in this function, its initialization and use elsewhere can affect overall flow analysis and potential unreachable code assumptions.
- malloc: Used to allocate con_info; its failure (NULL) causes an early return — needed to know if that return is reachable.
- free: Called on con_info when postprocessor creation fails — needed to verify that following code is/ is not reachable after free.
- strcmp: Used to distinguish GET/POST and the initial method checks; correctness/behavior of these comparisons determines which branches are reachable.
- MHD_create_post_processor: Called when method is POST; whether it can return NULL (and under what conditions) affects reachability of the error-return branch and subsequent code.
- MHD_post_process: Called when upload data present; its return value controls an early return (MHD_NO), and side effects may alter con_info->answerstring — both affect reachability of later branches.
- iterate_post: The callback passed to MHD_create_post_processor; it may write into con_info (for example, set answerstring). Knowing its possible side effects is necessary to determine if later branches (answerstring non-NULL) can be reached.
- POSTBUFFERSIZE: Size passed to MHD_create_post_processor; while not directly affecting branching, it is part of the post-processor creation call; extreme values could affect whether creation fails — relevant to reachability of the failure branch.
- POST: Symbol used to set connectiontype when method is POST; included to fully understand assignment semantics (affects external analysis of reachability where connectiontype matters).
- GET: Same reason as POST for completeness of control-flow reasoning.
- enum MHD_Result: The function returns this type and compares returns against MHD_YES/MHD_NO; understanding the enum values and their meaning is necessary to judge whether return statements are valid and which branches terminate the function.
- MHD_YES: Value compared against and returned; needed to determine which code paths end the function.
- MHD_NO: Value compared against and returned; needed to determine which code paths end the function.
- send_page: Called in multiple branches to produce a response; its invocation is used as a return in branches — needed to decide whether subsequent code is reachable.
- askpage: Argument passed to send_page on GET when no req_cls; whether this path is reachable depends on the GET check and earlier req_cls logic.
- errorpage: Default page passed to send_page at the end of the function; included because reachability of the final return depends on prior branches failing to return.

These symbols collectively determine which branches can actually execute, which calls can fail or produce side effects (notably iterate_post and MHD_post_process), and which return statements terminate the function — all required to decide whether any statements in answer_to_connection are unreachable per the MISRA rule.
